conbody.p: Euca2ools 3.3.0 has the following new features.

row.entry: Feature
Description
Zip files eliminated when obtaining credentials.
Eliminates the need for the zip files to be produced by Eucalyptus's deprecated euca_conf --get-credentials command.
Euca2ools 3.3.0 now requires version 0.4 of the requestbuilder python library.
If you install euca2ools with HP-provided RPM packages, requestbuilder will be installed automatically.
All commands use AWS signature version 4 for for all services except S3.

It can additionally be enabled for S3 on a per-region basis with the s3-force-sigv4 region option in euca2ools.ini. Eucalyptus 4.2's object storage gateway is not compatible with AWS signature version 4.
Configuration for AWS's eu-central-1 region has been added.
This region covers AWS's new Frankfurt-based region.
A CloudFormation URL for the localhost region has been added.
This adds support for CloudFormation service.
Configuration for the retired Eucalyptus Community Cloud has been removed.
Eucalyptus Community Cloud has been integrated into the HP Helion community.
New load balancer commands.

entry.p: The eulb-describe-load-balancer-attributes and eulb-modify-lb-attributes commands provide the ability to inspect and modify load balancers' attributes.
The eulb-create-tags, eulb-describe-tags, and eulb-delete-tags commands allow one to create, view, and delete tags on load balancers, respectively.

row.entry: -A option added to ELB create policy command.
eulb-create-lb-policy gained a -A option that simplifies entering multiple attributes.
IAM roles commands can now be used inside an eval shell command.
Use euare-assumerole and euare-releaserole inside an eval shell command to assume IAM roles.
The EUARE_URL environment variable has been removed.
Use the AWS_IAM_URL variable instead.
For IAM commands that act on only one entity, those entities' names may now be supplied positionally.
For example, euare-usercreate alice works the same as euare-usercreate -u alice.
-w/--write-config option added to several commands.

euare-accountcreate, euare-usercreate, and euare-useraddkey gained a -w/--write-config option that allows them create new access keys and output a euca2ools.ini file instead of their usual output formats, simplifying credential distribution. The service URLs it generates will be based on the IAM service's DNS domain; if the IAM service is accessed by IP address, the output will not contain service URLs. The -d/--domain option can be used to override this by choosing the domain name explicitly. Finally, the -l/--set-default-user option allows the output to set the given user as the default user for the region. Two examples are shown below:
euare-useraddkey alice -w > ~/.euca/alice.ini
euare-accountcreate bob -wld mycloud.example.com | mail -s "Your credentials" bob@example.com
Two eucalyptus-specific services may now be specified in euca2ools.ini files.
bootstrap and properties services can be specified in the euca2ools.ini files.
Commands that bundle images no longer require private keys to run.
Images bundled without private keys will not be signed, and therefore, be incompatible with Eucalyptus 4.1 and earlier.
Commands that bundle images no longer require signing certificates to run.
Images bundled without signing certificates are incompatible with Eucalyptus 4.1 and earlier and cannot be unbundled without cloud administrator assistance.
Commands that bundle images can fetch the cloud's signing certificate automatically.

If the commands have been configured with the bootstrap service's endpoint and the cloud runs Eucalyptus or later. Normal users require the euserv:DescribeServiceCertificates capability in their IAM policies to use this functionality.
Two unbundle-related commands no longer process corrupt bundles.

Differences in digest zero-padding can cause euca-unbundle to fail. However, euca-unbundle and euca-download-and-unbundle ignores bundles with certain checksums to be corrupt and successfully unbundles them anyway.
